elements.content: Solids that combine long-range order with rapid molecular reorientation offer a promising approach for the development of a novel class of functional materials with potential applications in materials science and nanotechnology. In this contribution, the capability of dicarbollide ions to undergo self-assembly processes with suitable macromolecules is demonstrated, and a strategy leading to the formation of structurally and dynamically well-defined amphidynamic polymeric composites is introduced. For this purpose, three amphidynamic nanocomposites were synthesized via the self-assembly of cobalt bis(dicarbollide) anions (CoD–), with neutral poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO), and two isomers of poly(vinylpyridine), P2VP and P4VP, in protonated form. All of the systems were characterized by a combined study employing WAXS, advanced solid-state NMR, and quantum chemical calculations. It was found out that the interaction of neutral PEO with CoD– ions driven by weak dihydrogen bonding resulted in the formation of a uniquely organized periodic structure. In contrast, the self-assembly of the systems based on the electrostatic interactions (charge-transfer-assisted hydrogen bonding) of P2(4)VP was controlled by the position of the positive charge in pyridine ring and resulted in unique well-defined orientations of the CoD– ions (parallel and perpendicular) with respect to the polymer chains. In addition, the CoD– ions exhibited uniaxial relatively large-amplitude rotational motions in all of the nanocomposites over the broad range of T g. The motional amplitudes executed by the CoD– ions are significantly more extensive than those of the polymer segments in all of the systems. Macromolecules thus represent a rigid support (stator) for the more mobile CoD– ions (rotators). The obtained findings revealed that a relatively simple self-assembly procedure could be used for the preparation of well-defined amphidynamic nanocomposites, thereby opening a route to construct sophisticated supramolecular systems.

elements.content: Since the 1960s, the concept of nanostructured materials has attracted worldwide attention, and the process of self-controlled assembly of suitable molecules has been extensively studied. Currently, nanostructured systems with tailored properties represent prospective materials for solving many scientific problems.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Since the 1960s, the concept of nanostructured materials has attracted worldwide attention, and the process of self-controlled assembly of suitable molecules has been extensively studied. Currently, nanostructured systems with tailored properties represent prospective materials for solving many scientific problems.

elements.content: Over the past decades, a number of nanostructured systems have been developed. Of these systems, amphidynamic assemblies that combine long-range molecular order with well-defined site-specific dynamics represent a promising class of functional materials, potentially leading to artificial molecular machines. In this respect, crystalline organic molecules in which mobile elements are covalently bound to rigid segments have been the focus of extensive investigation. To date, considerable progress has been made toward the development of fully covalent machines, such as molecular gyroscopes and compasses. In contrast, there are a limited number of reports that address artificial supramolecular devices, most likely because supramolecular synthesis that relies on weak noncovalent interactions must overcome many fundamental obstacles and requires a careful choice of building blocks with complementary geometries and binding patterns. Recent work in the area of the controlled assembly of suitable building segments has resulted in the creation of nanomechanical tweezers, supramolecular valves, four-component double-ball bearing complexes, and four-component supramolecular nanorotors.

In this respect, crystalline organic molecules in which mobile elements are covalently bound to rigid segments have been the focus of extensive investigation. To date, considerable progress has been made toward the development of fully covalent machines, such as molecular gyroscopes and compasses. In contrast, there are a limited number of reports that address artificial supramolecular devices, most likely because supramolecular synthesis that relies on weak noncovalent interactions must overcome many fundamental obstacles and requires a careful choice of building blocks with complementary geometries and binding patterns. Recent work in the area of the controlled assembly of suitable building segments has resulted in the creation of nanomechanical tweezers, supramolecular valves, four-component double-ball bearing complexes, and four-component supramolecular nanorotors.

elements.content: Despite the success of biological macromolecules in forming sophisticated autonomous and collective supramolecular machineries (e.g., F0F1-ATP synthase, bacterial flagella, and skeletal muscles), the self-assembly of synthetic macromolecules is considerably less effective. Among the many complicating factors, the finding specific molecular recognition sites and controlling the weak, mostly reversible interactions are the most crucial. In this respect, metallacarboranes represented by cobalt bis(dicarbollide)(−1) ions (CoD–) in combination with suitable polymers exhibit promising potential for creating supramolecular systems with unique 3D architectures. This effect is attributed to both the amphiphilic character of the CoD– ions resulting from the delocalized negative charge over a large surface and the uniaxial symmetry that allows for the execution of well-defined molecular motions. In this respect, molecular rotors based on single-cluster carborane compounds have already been studied.
elements.clean_text: Despite the success of biological macromolecules in forming sophisticated autonomous and collective supramolecular machineries (e.g., F0F1-ATP synthase, bacterial flagella, and skeletal muscles), the self-assembly of synthetic macromolecules is considerably less effective. Among the many complicating factors, the finding specific molecular recognition sites and controlling the weak, mostly reversible interactions are the most crucial. In this respect, metallacarboranes represented by cobalt bis(dicarbollide)(-1) ions (CoD-) in combination with suitable polymers exhibit promising potential for creating supramolecular systems with unique 3D architectures. This effect is attributed to both the amphiphilic character of the CoD- ions resulting from the delocalized negative charge over a large surface and the uniaxial symmetry that allows for the execution of well-defined molecular motions. In this respect, molecular rotors based on single-cluster carborane compounds have already been studied.

elements.content: In our previous work, we suggested that nontraditional hydrogen bonding played an active role in the formation of regular complexes of CoD– ions with poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO); however, the influence of polymer segments on the self-assembly process and local motions has not been fully described. Therefore, to increase the pool of structural information, we have prepared new types of polymer/metallacarborane composites. In addition to the previously applied neutral, conformationally flexible chains of PEO with a low glass transition temperature (T g), the positively charged, relatively rigid macromolecules of poly(2-vinylpyridine) (P2VP) and poly(4-vinylpyridine) (P4VP) with considerably higher T g were used (Scheme ). The P2(4)VP/metallacarborane composites were synthesized via a self-controlled molecular assembly process. The structures and dynamics of all the prepared polymer/metallacarborane complexes were investigated in detail.

Therefore, to increase the pool of structural information, we have prepared new types of polymer/metallacarborane composites. In addition to the previously applied neutral, conformationally flexible chains of PEO with a low glass transition temperature (T g), the positively charged, relatively rigid macromolecules of poly(2-vinylpyridine) (P2VP) and poly(4-vinylpyridine) (P4VP) with considerably higher T g were used (Scheme ). The P2(4)VP/metallacarborane composites were synthesized via a self-controlled molecular assembly process. elements.content: The primary aim of our contribution is to demonstrate the capability of dicarbollide ions to undergo self-assembly processes with macromolecules and form well-defined amphidynamic composites. To obtain high-quality structural information, a wide range of solid-state NMR experiments combined with wide-angle X-ray scattering (WAXS) and quantum chemical predictions were applied. Particularly, homonuclear and heteronuclear 1H–1H, 11B–11B, and 1H–11B correlation techniques and separation-local-field (SLF) experiments allowing for the measurement of 1H–11B and 1H–13C dipolar couplings were employed. Thus, the present contribution provides not only information on the structure and dynamics of polymer/metallacarborane nanocomposites but also a guide for characterizing nanostructured organoboron amphidynamic solids.

elements.content: The cesium salt of the metallacarborane anion [3-cobalt(III) bis(1,2-dicarbollide)](−1), CsCoD] was purchased from Katchem Ltd. and converted to NaCoD·4H2O by the extraction described previously. The X-ray crystal structure was determined using a Nonius Kappa CCD diffractometer, Bruker, Karlsruhe, Germany, using monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å) at 150(2) K (for the CIF, see the ). The poly(ethylene oxide), PEO, with a weight-averaged molecular weight M w = 41 500, dispersity Đ = 1.10, and T g = −66 °C, was purchased from Fluka. The poly(2-vinylpyridine), P2VP (M w = 37 500; Đ = 1.07, T g = 104 °C), and poly(4-vinylpyridine), P4VP (M w = 68 000; Đ = 1.11, T g = 142 °C), were purchased from Aldrich (Scheme ).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

The cesium salt of the metallacarborane anion [3-cobalt(III) bis(1,2-dicarbollide)](-1), CsCoD] was purchased from Katchem Ltd. and converted to NaCoD⋅4H2O by the extraction described previously. The X-ray crystal structure was determined using a Nonius Kappa CCD diffractometer, Bruker, Karlsruhe, Germany, using monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 150(2) K (for the CIF, see the ). The poly(ethylene oxide), PEO, with a weight-averaged molecular weight M w = 41500, dispersity   Đ   = 1.10, and T g = -66 °C, was purchased from Fluka. The poly(2-vinylpyridine), P2VP (M w = 37500;   Đ   = 1.07, T g = 104 °C), and poly(4-vinylpyridine), P4VP (M w = 68000;   Đ   = 1.11, T g = 142 °C), were purchased from Aldrich (Scheme ).

elements.content: The polymer/metallacarborane composites were prepared in a dialysis tube through the self-assembly process. To prepare the PEO/Na+/CoD– complex, a dialysis tube containing an aqueous solution of PEO was placed into a beaker containing 0.5 L of a NaCoD solution in 0.1 M NaCl. (No composites were formed in pure aqueous solution of NaCoD because Na+ ions shift the equilibrium toward the composite formation.) In contrast, the P2(4)VP/H+/CoD– composites were prepared in dialysis tubes with acidic aqueous solutions of P2(4)VP (0.1 M HCl), which were placed into beakers containing a dilute NaCoD solution (0.1 M HCl). The resulting P2(4)VP segment-to-HCl ratio was 1:50. As P2(4)VPs are weak polycations, applying low pH ensures complete protonization. The PEO/Na+/CoD– and P2(4)VP/H+/CoD– precipitates that spontaneously formed within one month were carefully removed from the dialysis tubes, washed several times with water, and dried in a vacuum oven.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of the Polymer/Metallacarborane Assemblies

The polymer/metallacarborane composites were prepared in a dialysis tube through the self-assembly process. To prepare the PEO/Na+/CoD- complex, a dialysis tube containing an aqueous solution of PEO was placed into a beaker containing 0.5 L of a NaCoD solution in 0.1 M NaCl. (No composites were formed in pure aqueous solution of NaCoD because Na+ ions shift the equilibrium toward the composite formation.) In contrast, the P2(4)VP/H+/CoD- composites were prepared in dialysis tubes with acidic aqueous solutions of P2(4)VP (0.1 M HCl), which were placed into beakers containing a dilute NaCoD solution (0.1 M HCl). The resulting P2(4)VP segment-to-HCl ratio was 1:50. As P2(4)VPs are weak polycations, applying low pH ensures complete protonization. The PEO/Na+/CoD- and P2(4)VP/H+/CoD- precipitates that spontaneously formed within one month were carefully removed from the dialysis tubes, washed several times with water, and dried in a vacuum oven.

elements.content: WAXS experiments were performed using a pinhole camera (Molecular Metrology System) attached to a microfocused X-ray beam generator (Osmic MicroMax 002) operating at 45 kV and 0.66 mA (30 W). The samples were measured in transmission mode using interchangeable 23 × 25 cm imaging plates (Fujifilm). The q range for the WAXS was 0.25–3.5 Å–1 (q = (4π/λ) sin θ, λ = 1.54 Å, 2θ is the scattering angle). The center and sample-to-detector distance were calibrated using Si powder.
elements.clean_text:
Wide-Angle X-ray Scattering (WAXS)

WAXS experiments were performed using a pinhole camera (Molecular Metrology System) attached to a microfocused X-ray beam generator (Osmic MicroMax 002) operating at 45 kV and 0.66 mA (30 W). The samples were measured in transmission mode using interchangeable 23 × 25 cm imaging plates (Fujifilm). The q range for the WAXS was 0.25-3.5 Å-1 (q = (4π/λ) sin θ, λ = 1.54 Å, 2θ is the scattering angle). The center and sample-to-detector distance were calibrated using Si powder.

elements.content: Solid-state NMR spectra were measured at 11.7 T using a Bruker Avance III HD 500 US/WB NMR spectrometer (Karlsruhe, Germany, 2013). The following techniques were applied: (i) one-dimensional (1D) 1H, 11B, 13C, and 15N MAS and CP/MAS NMR experiments; (ii) two-dimensional (2D) homonuclear double-quantum (DQ) 1H–1H back-to-back (BABA) and 1H–1H spin-diffusion correlation experiments with the DUMBO homodecoupling sequence; (iii) 2D heteronuclear 1H–13C and 1H–11B FSLG HETCOR experiments; (iv) 2D homonuclear 11B–11B proton-driven spin-diffusion (PDSD) technique and 11B–11B DQ experiment with a BR21 2 recoupling sequence; and (v) 2D separated local fields T 1-filtered PISEMAS, PILGRIM, and WISE experiments. The frictional heating of the spinning samples was compensated by active cooling, temperature gradients were minimized using spherical spacers, and temperature calibrations were performed with Pb(NO3)2. The detailed experimental parameters are provided in S1.
elements.clean_text:
Solid-State NMR (ss-NMR)

Solid-state NMR spectra were measured at 11.7 T using a Bruker Avance III HD 500 US/WB NMR spectrometer (Karlsruhe, Germany, 2013). The following techniques were applied: (i) one-dimensional (1D) 1H, 11B, 13C, and 15N MAS and CP/MAS NMR experiments; (ii) two-dimensional (2D) homonuclear double-quantum (DQ) 1H-1H back-to-back (BABA) and 1H-1H spin-diffusion correlation experiments with the DUMBO homodecoupling sequence; (iii) 2D heteronuclear 1H-13C and 1H-11B FSLG HETCOR experiments; (iv) 2D homonuclear 11B-11B proton-driven spin-diffusion (PDSD) technique and 11B-11B DQ experiment with a BR21 2 recoupling sequence; and (v) 2D separated local fields T 1-filtered PISEMAS, PILGRIM, and WISE experiments. The frictional heating of the spinning samples was compensated by active cooling, temperature gradients were minimized using spherical spacers, and temperature calibrations were performed with Pb(NO3)2. The detailed experimental parameters are provided in  S1.

elements.content: Infrared spectra were recorded on a Thermo Nicolet Magna 760 IR instrument equipped with an Inspector IR using both undiluted and KBr-diluted samples. The diffuse reflectance technique (128 or more scans at a resolution of 4 cm–1) was used.
elements.clean_text:
Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR)

Infrared spectra were recorded on a Thermo Nicolet Magna 760 IR instrument equipped with an Inspector IR using both undiluted and KBr-diluted samples. The diffuse reflectance technique (128 or more scans at a resolution of 4 cm-1) was used.

elements.content: ITC measurements were performed using an isothermal titration calorimeter (Nano ITC), TA Instruments - Waters LLC, New Castle, DE. The microcalorimeter consisted of a reference cell and a sample cell (24 K gold). The sample cell was connected to a 50 μL syringe. The syringe needle was equipped with a flattened, twisted paddle at the tip, which ensured continuous mixing of the solutions in the cell rotating at 250 rpm. The titrations were performed by consecutive 2.02 μL injections of 0.0245 M NaCoD in 0.1 M HCl from the syringe into the sample cell filled with 193 μL of 0.83 g/L P2(4)VP in 0.1 M HCl. A total of 50 injections were performed at intervals of 1200 s. The raw heat changes were analyzed by NITPIC software to obtain ITC thermograms.
elements.clean_text:
Isothermal Titration Calorimetry (ITC)

ITC measurements were performed using an isothermal titration calorimeter (Nano ITC), TA Instruments - Waters LLC, New Castle, DE. The microcalorimeter consisted of a reference cell and a sample cell (24 K gold). The sample cell was connected to a 50 μL syringe. The syringe needle was equipped with a flattened, twisted paddle at the tip, which ensured continuous mixing of the solutions in the cell rotating at 250 rpm. The titrations were performed by consecutive 2.02 μL injections of 0.0245 M NaCoD in 0.1 M HCl from the syringe into the sample cell filled with 193 μL of 0.83 g/L P2(4)VP in 0.1 M HCl. A total of 50 injections were performed at intervals of 1200 s. The raw heat changes were analyzed by NITPIC software to obtain ITC thermograms.

elements.content: The P2VP and P4VP polymer chains were each approximated using the trimer structure capped with methyl groups (the approach was successfully employed to study the recognition of small molecules by poly(vinyldiaminotriazine)). Using interactive computer graphics software (program Insight II (2000), Accelrys Inc., San Diego, CA), several initial arrangements of the cluster were prepared consisting of a single cobalt bis(dicarbollide)(−1) ion, two chloride(−1) ions, and the polymer model. These configurations were subjected to full geometrical optimization using the RI-MP2 (resolution-of-the-identity integral approximation to the second-order Møller–Plesset perturbation theory) method applied together with the SVP (single-valence plus polarization) atomic and auxiliary orbital basis sets. The lowest-energy structures obtained for the P2VP- and P4VP-containing clusters were reoptimized using the RI-MP2 method and the TZVP (triple-ζ valence plus polarization) atomic and auxiliary basis functions. All of the calculations were performed using the TURBOMOLE V6.5 software.
elements.clean_text:
Quantum Chemical Calculations

The P2VP and P4VP polymer chains were each approximated using the trimer structure capped with methyl groups (the approach was successfully employed to study the recognition of small molecules by poly(vinyldiaminotriazine)). Using interactive computer graphics software (program Insight II (2000), Accelrys Inc., San Diego, CA), several initial arrangements of the cluster were prepared consisting of a single cobalt bis(dicarbollide)(-1) ion, two chloride(-1) ions, and the polymer model. These configurations were subjected to full geometrical optimization using the RI-MP2 (resolution-of-the-identity integral approximation to the second-order Møller-Plesset perturbation theory) method applied together with the SVP (single-valence plus polarization) atomic and auxiliary orbital basis sets. The lowest-energy structures obtained for the P2VP- and P4VP-containing clusters were reoptimized using the RI-MP2 method and the TZVP (triple-ζ valence plus polarization) atomic and auxiliary basis functions. All of the calculations were performed using the TURBOMOLE V6.5 software.

elements.content: As demonstrated by the ITC thermograms (Figure ), the formation of polymer/metallacarborane composites proceeds differently for the three investigated systems. The precipitation of the PEO/Na+/CoD– composite (deeply red solid with T g < 0 °C) is driven by a combination of several weak effects including dihydrogen bonding of B–H···H–C moieties, complexation of Na+ by PEO, electrostatic attraction of CoD– and Na+, and desolvation. This occurrence is essentially a two-step process in which a simple interaction of CoD– clusters with PEO is accompanied by a highly exothermic “aggregation” peak at the molar ratio of ca. 0.07, which is related to the reorganization of metallacarborane clusters within the PEO matrix. The interaction of P2VP and P4VP polycations with CoD– anions is based on a direct electrostatic attraction that leads to the formation of orange powders with T g = 167 and 242 °C determined by DSC for P2VP/H+/CoD– and P4VP/H+/CoD–, respectively. However, only the formation of P2VP/H+/CoD– could be described by a simple one-site binding model. For P4VP, the thermogram is flat with no single distinct “step”. There are at least two consecutive processes, as demonstrated by the mild steps at molar ratios of 0.3 and 0.7 (Figure c). From the significant differences in the thermograms for P2VP and P4VP, it is clear that the position of the positively charged groups in the pyridine rings plays an important role in the formation of the nanocomposite. The thermodynamic characteristics are shown in S2.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Formation of Polymer/Metallacarborane Assemblies (ITC and WAXS)

As demonstrated by the ITC thermograms (Figure ), the formation of polymer/metallacarborane composites proceeds differently for the three investigated systems. The precipitation of the PEO/Na+/CoD- composite (deeply red solid with T g < 0 °C) is driven by a combination of several weak effects including dihydrogen bonding of B-H⋅⋅⋅H-C moieties, complexation of Na+ by PEO, electrostatic attraction of CoD- and Na+, and desolvation. This occurrence is essentially a two-step process in which a simple interaction of CoD- clusters with PEO is accompanied by a highly exothermic "aggregation" peak at the molar ratio of ca. 0.07, which is related to the reorganization of metallacarborane clusters within the PEO matrix. The interaction of P2VP and P4VP polycations with CoD- anions is based on a direct electrostatic attraction that leads to the formation of orange powders with T g = 167 and 242 °C determined by DSC for P2VP/H+/CoD- and P4VP/H+/CoD-, respectively. However, only the formation of P2VP/H+/CoD- could be described by a simple one-site binding model. For P4VP, the thermogram is flat with no single distinct "step". There are at least two consecutive processes, as demonstrated by the mild steps at molar ratios of 0.3 and 0.7 (Figure c). From the significant differences in the thermograms for P2VP and P4VP, it is clear that the position of the positively charged groups in the pyridine rings plays an important role in the formation of the nanocomposite. The thermodynamic characteristics are shown in  S2.

elements.content: As indicated by the X-ray diffraction data (Figure ), differences in the self-assembly processes have a significant impact on the global architecture of the resulting composites. While WAXS peaks at 19.1° and 23.2° indicated crystalline domains adopting helical conformation of polymer chains in parent PEO, no such peaks were found for PEO/Na+/CoD– composite revealing that the periodic structure of PEO completely disappeared due to the interaction with CoD– clusters and Na+ ions. The absence of crystalline domains of PEO was further confirmed by DSC and solid-state 13C MAS NMR. Consequently, the narrow reflections detected for PEO/Na+/CoD– (Figure ) confirm the creation of long-range periodically ordered assemblies of NaCoD in the PEO matrix. In contrast, the broad diffusive reflections indicate that the P2(4)VP/H+/CoD– nanocomposites remain amorphous.

While WAXS peaks at 19.1° and 23.2° indicated crystalline domains adopting helical conformation of polymer chains in parent PEO, no such peaks were found for PEO/Na+/CoD- composite revealing that the periodic structure of PEO completely disappeared due to the interaction with CoD- clusters and Na+ ions. The absence of crystalline domains of PEO was further confirmed by DSC and solid-state 13C MAS NMR. Consequently, the narrow reflections detected for PEO/Na+/CoD- (Figure ) confirm the creation of long-range periodically ordered assemblies of NaCoD in the PEO matrix. In contrast, the broad diffusive reflections indicate that the P2(4)VP/H+/CoD- nanocomposites remain amorphous.

elements.content: To complement the X-ray diffraction data and to obtain information on the structures of amorphous systems with atomic-scale resolution, a range of solid-state NMR experiments was applied. As reflected by the line shapes of the recorded 13C, 15N, and 11B solid-state NMR spectra (Figure ), all of the building units were considerably rearranged upon formation of the polymer/metallacarborane nanocomposites. Specifically, the broad signal of crystalline PEO completely disappeared; a narrow signal of amorphous PEO moved toward lower frequencies and split into two signals (68.0 and 69.5 ppm); and the asymmetrically broadened signal of C′1,2 units narrowed (Figure a). The narrowing of the signal representing C′1,2 groups observed in the nanocomposites indicates that effective local symmetry in the vicinity of CoD– clusters increased probably as a result of enhanced segmental dynamics. As demonstrated by the large shifts in the 13C NMR resonances in the frequency region of aromatic carbons (e.g., C1; Figure a), the rearrangement of P2VP and P4VP segments is accompanied by protonation of pyridine −N sites simultaneously with binding of CoD– ions. The extensive charge-transfer-assisted hydrogen bonding, which leads to the formation of pyridinium, −N(H+), units, is confirmed by the large shifts toward the low-frequency region in the 15N CP/MAS NMR (Figure c) and FTIR spectra (CN stretching vibration at 1590–1595 cm–1, S2). The observed broadening of the 15N CP/MAS NMR signals then indicates considerable structural variation in the pyridinium moieties that differ in −N···H+ hydrogen-bonding strength. 11B MAS NMR spectra then reflect differences in the arrangement of metallacarborane clusters. Specifically, the observed narrowing and shift of the signals of B8 and B10 sites (clearly seen for PEO/Na+/CoD–, Figure b) indicate that local structure around them is considerably changed when nanocomposites are formed.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization of Nanocomposites by 13C, 15N, and 11B ss-NMR

To complement the X-ray diffraction data and to obtain information on the structures of amorphous systems with atomic-scale resolution, a range of solid-state NMR experiments was applied. As reflected by the line shapes of the recorded 13C, 15N, and 11B solid-state NMR spectra (Figure ), all of the building units were considerably rearranged upon formation of the polymer/metallacarborane nanocomposites. Specifically, the broad signal of crystalline PEO completely disappeared; a narrow signal of amorphous PEO moved toward lower frequencies and split into two signals (68.0 and 69.5 ppm); and the asymmetrically broadened signal of C'1,2 units narrowed (Figure a). The narrowing of the signal representing C'1,2 groups observed in the nanocomposites indicates that effective local symmetry in the vicinity of CoD- clusters increased probably as a result of enhanced segmental dynamics. As demonstrated by the large shifts in the 13C NMR resonances in the frequency region of aromatic carbons (e.g., C1; Figure a), the rearrangement of P2VP and P4VP segments is accompanied by protonation of pyridine -N sites simultaneously with binding of CoD- ions. The extensive charge-transfer-assisted hydrogen bonding, which leads to the formation of pyridinium, -N(H+), units, is confirmed by the large shifts toward the low-frequency region in the 15N CP/MAS NMR (Figure c) and FTIR spectra (CN stretching vibration at 1590-1595 cm-1,  S2). The observed broadening of the 15N CP/MAS NMR signals then indicates considerable structural variation in the pyridinium moieties that differ in -N⋅⋅⋅H+ hydrogen-bonding strength. 11B MAS NMR spectra then reflect differences in the arrangement of metallacarborane clusters. Specifically, the observed narrowing and shift of the signals of B8 and B10 sites (clearly seen for PEO/Na+/CoD-, Figure b) indicate that local structure around them is considerably changed when nanocomposites are formed.

elements.content: Because the stoichiometry of the composites is not strictly controlled by the composition of the reaction mixtures but rather results from many competitive processes, solid-state NMR experiments were employed to obtain complementary data. To obtain quantitative ss-NMR data, we measured 13C MAS NMR spectra with the repetition delay (120 s) being ca. 5 times longer than the T 1(13C) relaxation time of the carbons used for the signal integration (e.g., T 1(13C) = 26 s for C2,6 of P4VP). The results then revealed that the PEO/Na+/CoD– composite contains 14.0 ± 0.5 PEO segments per 1 CoD– anion, whereas there are 2.3 ± 0.2 and 1.6 ± 0.2 PVP monomer units per 1 CoD– cluster in the P2VP/H+/CoD– and P4VP/H+/CoD– systems, respectively (Table ). This finding confirms that the positive charge of the pyridinium sites is compensated not only by the dicarbollide CoD– clusters but also by the Cl– ions, thus leading to questions regarding the binding capacity of the polymer chains and the distribution of CoD– ions along them.

elements.content: When analyzing the homogeneity of multicomponent solids, ss-NMR spectroscopy traditionally relies on the measurement of 1H–1H spin diffusion. Of the many possible ss-NMR experiments, the recently developed 2D 1H–1H DUMBO spin-diffusion experiment combining high sensitivity with enhanced spectral resolution offers a powerful tool to probe early stages of polarization transfer at even interfacial area. Consequently, the 1H–1H DUMBO correlation spectra of the polymer/metallacarborane nanocomposites measured with short mixing times τm showing well-evolved intercomponent correlations indicate the existence of a large fraction of CoD– ions that intimately interact with the polymer chains (τm = 20–60 μs, Figure a and S3). For more precise measurement of domain sizes we recorded 1H–13C FSLG HETCOR spectra, in which the key intercomponent correlations were better resolved (Figure b and S3).

Distribution of Dicarbollide Ions (Size of CoD- Domains)

When analyzing the homogeneity of multicomponent solids, ss-NMR spectroscopy traditionally relies on the measurement of 1H-1H spin diffusion. Of the many possible ss-NMR experiments, the recently developed 2D 1H-1H DUMBO spin-diffusion experiment combining high sensitivity with enhanced spectral resolution offers a powerful tool to probe early stages of polarization transfer at even interfacial area. Consequently, the 1H-1H DUMBO correlation spectra of the polymer/metallacarborane nanocomposites measured with short mixing times τm showing well-evolved intercomponent correlations indicate the existence of a large fraction of CoD- ions that intimately interact with the polymer chains (τm = 20-60 μs, Figure a and  S3). For more precise measurement of domain sizes we recorded 1H-13C FSLG HETCOR spectra, in which the key intercomponent correlations were better resolved (Figure b and  S3).

elements.content: After integration of the 2D 1H–13C FSLG HETCOR correlation signals between CoD– carbons and polymer protons (e.g., H3,5–C′1,2, Figure b) measured with a variable spin-diffusion mixing time, t m (50–5500 μs), we reconstructed the spin-diffusion build-up curves that were used to determine the equilibrium spin-exchange mixing times, t eq (Figure c). By applying the generally accepted model describing the linear part of the spin-diffusion process, the long pathway of polarization transfer (x) was estimated using the equation x = ε f pol 4 D eff t eq π where D eff is effective spin-diffusion coefficient (see S3) and ε = 1–3 is the scaling factor that reflects the dimensionality of the spin-diffusion process.

elements.content: Regardless of the dimensionality of the spin diffusion, the calculated polarization transfer pathways revealed very short length scale (0.4–1.1 nm) over which CoD– ions and PEO chains are mixed. Bearing in mind the effective size of CoD– ions x CoD = (l.d)0.5 = 0.81 nm (Scheme ) the PEO/Na+/CoD– composite represents a system in which both components are intimately mixed and extensive phase separation can be excluded. In contrast, in the P2(4)VP composites in which the volume fractions of CoD– ions are relatively high, some type of metallacarborane clustering should be expected. Assuming two-dimensional 1H spin diffusion from the rod-like P2(4)VP polymers (ε = 2), the characteristic diffusive pathway is ca. 2.0 nm, indicating formation of nanosized domains in P2VP/H+/CoD– composite. Considerably longer polarization transfer pathways were found for the P4VP/H+/CoD– (Table ). Considering that the volume fraction of CoD– ions reached 63%, it is reasonable to assume that dicarbollide ions form continuous or semicontinuous phase with the characteristic dimension of ca. 3.5–4.0 nm.

Volume fraction of the polymer matrix (f pol) was estimated from the molar compositions, n, and densities of the individual components: ρ(PEO) = 1.12 g cm–3, ρ(P4VP) = 1.15 g cm–3, and ρ(NaCoD·4H2O) = 1.38 g cm–3. For the control, a maximum diffusive pathway (L) was calculated according to the relation L = (6D eff t eq)0.5.

The combination of a high gyromagnetic ratio and the 80% natural abundance of 11B isotopes motivates the application of 11B–11B NMR correlation spectroscopy for probing the self-aggregation of dicarbollide ions. However, the compact molecular structure of CoD– units, in which all boron atoms interact with each other, results in complicated 11B–11B PDSD NMR correlation spectra that exhibit the superposition of structurally relevant intermolecular correlations with much stronger intramolecular ones ( S4). To simplify the correlation pattern, we utilized the recently developed the 2D DQ BR21 2 NMR correlation technique that, in contrast to 2D 11B–11B PDSD, suppresses the relayed spin-diffusion transfer and allows for the evolution of autocorrelation signals when equivalent nuclei are spatially close only. To aid in the interpretation of the 11B–11B DQ BR21 2 NMR spectra, we analyzed 11B–11B correlations for model crystalline compounds with known structures. Nevertheless the interpretations presented below are preliminary, and rigorous discussion would require theoretical extensive simulations of 11B–11B double-quantum coherence evolution in these compact multiple-spin systems (e.g., boron atom no. 11 is directly coupled with five other boron sites). In this regard we assume that applying the relatively long recoupling time the long-range coherences will be relatively enhanced, whereas the one-bond coherences suppressed.

In this regard we assume that applying the relatively long recoupling time the long-range coherences will be relatively enhanced, whereas the one-bond coherences suppressed.

elements.content: The systematic variation of B 1-field power and DQ recoupling mixing time (τmix) made on the well-defined model system (borax) showed that the efficient evolution of long-range correlations for 11B spins separated by 3.6–4.1 Å requires applying of τmix = 0.6–1.0 ms (3–5 recoupling loops at 20 kHz MAS, S5). Similar optimizations made for neat CsCoD and the prepared nanocomposites revealed that optimum DQ excitation/reconversion time is 0.6 ms. Consequently, we suppose that the long-range correlations detected for crystalline CsCoD with τmix = 0.6 ms reflect both intra- and intermolecular contacts because they correspond to the distances of ca. 2.9 and 4.0 Å, respectively (Figure a, correlation signals B8–B11, B5–B11, and B6–B4). The performed optimization further revealed that T 2 relaxation processes, generally affecting buildup of 11B DQ coherences, are nearly identical for all metallacarborane systems. Consequently the structure of prepared composites could be probed by focusing on these correlations (Figure b–d). Although these long-range correlations are relatively weak in P4VP/H+/CoD– (Figure d), they are still detectable, indicating thus presence of non-negligible population of assemblies with an arrangement comparable to that of CsCoD crystals ( S6). These long-range correlations, however, do not evolve in P2VP/H+/CoD–, suggesting the absence of a specific arrangement of CoD– clusters in this composite. The poor correlation pattern and the relatively enhanced intensity of the correlation signals involving B10 boron units observed for PEO/Na+/CoD– indicate a weakening of the 11B–11B dipolar couplings resulting from the isolation of CoD– ions and their specific motions, as discussed below.

elements.content: The intimate mixing and nanoheterogeneous nature of the investigated composites indicate that the physicochemical properties will primarily depend on the structuring at large interfacial area. In particular, arrangements in the interfacial zone will be the key factors for reaching the specific dynamics of the CoD– ions.
elements.clean_text:
Interfacial Arrangement

The intimate mixing and nanoheterogeneous nature of the investigated composites indicate that the physicochemical properties will primarily depend on the structuring at large interfacial area. In particular, arrangements in the interfacial zone will be the key factors for reaching the specific dynamics of the CoD- ions.

elements.content: To probe the interface, the initial stage of 1H–13C and 1H–11B cross-polarization transfer was analyzed. At the shortest mixing-time applied (τm = 150 μs) the intermolecular proton–carbon correlations clearly evolved for CoD– clusters and pyridine side chains, (Py)H4,6–(CoD–)C1,2′, while for the evolution of correlations including main-chain protons, H7,8–(CoD–)C1,2′, a longer mixing time (τm = 300–500 μs) was necessary. These findings thus indicate that CoD– clusters are tightly packed along the P2VP chain and occupy the position that is very close to the pyridine side chains and not far from the polymer backbone (e.g., structural model in Figure a, S3). In contrast, for the P4VP/H+/CoD– composite, the short mixing time intermolecular correlations evolved for −NC–H pyridine protons H3,5 (Figure b, correlation signal (Py)H3,5–(CoD)C1,2′), whereas the intermolecular correlation between the P4VP main-chain protons H7,8 and the CoD– carbons was not detected even when applying τm = 500 μs. (These correlation signals were observed in the spectra recorded with τm ≥ 650 μs.) This indicates the CoD– ions in the P4VP/H+/CoD– composite are preferentially located close to the N–H+ sites and relatively far from the polymer backbone (e.g., structural model in Figure b).

elements.content: Complementary data were derived from the 1H–11B FSLG HETCOR spectra, in which the resonances of boron sites B6, B8, and B10 were well resolved (Figure ). The strong correlation between PEO protons and B10 atoms evolved within τm = 50 μs indicates close spatial proximity between B–H···H–C segments in PEO/Na+/CoD– complex (the mentioned correlation signal is indicated by the intersection of dashed lines; Figure a). In contrast, in the P2(4)VP composites the corresponding correlation signals between the pyridine protons and B10 sites are barely detectable at the same mixing time (Figure b,c). This observation suggests that, in contrast to PEO/Na+/CoD–, the B10 boron sites of CoD– are not preferentially involved in the interactions with protons of positively charged pyridine rings.

elements.content: A series of RIMP2-based energy minimizations were performed to examine the structural assumptions derived from the experimental data. Because noncovalent interactions of CoD– ions and PEO segments have been recently investigated using a computational approach and because extensive computational efforts have indicated the formation of nontraditional “di-hydrogen” bonding between PEO and CoD– protons B–H···H–C with H-bond length of 1.8–2.3 Å, our investigation focused on elucidating the specific interactions between CoD– ions and the P2VP and P4VP polymer segments. The molecular models used for the structure optimizations consisted of trimers of P2(4)VP chains in protonated form accompanied by a single CoD– cluster and two chloride ions. In this respect we assume that the nanocomposites are close to equilibrated state because they were formed by extremely slow process the time scale of which was from weeks to months. Consequently, although the local arrangement is not uniform over the entire sample, the predicted structures hopefully represent the most preferred structural motifs in the prepared PVP/metallacarborane composites. Typical features in the local arrangements in the composites proposed by quantum chemical calculations are illustrated in Figure .
elements.clean_text:
Quantum Chemical Calculations

A series of RIMP2-based energy minimizations were performed to examine the structural assumptions derived from the experimental data. Because noncovalent interactions of CoD- ions and PEO segments have been recently investigated using a computational approach and because extensive computational efforts have indicated the formation of nontraditional "di-hydrogen" bonding between PEO and CoD- protons B-H⋅⋅⋅H-C with H-bond length of 1.8-2.3 Å, our investigation focused on elucidating the specific interactions between CoD- ions and the P2VP and P4VP polymer segments. The molecular models used for the structure optimizations consisted of trimers of P2(4)VP chains in protonated form accompanied by a single CoD- cluster and two chloride ions. In this respect we assume that the nanocomposites are close to equilibrated state because they were formed by extremely slow process the time scale of which was from weeks to months. Consequently, although the local arrangement is not uniform over the entire sample, the predicted structures hopefully represent the most preferred structural motifs in the prepared PVP/metallacarborane composites. Typical features in the local arrangements in the composites proposed by quantum chemical calculations are illustrated in Figure .

elements.content: Quantum-chemically optimized (RIMP2/TZVP) geometries of local structures in P2VP/H+/CoD– (a) and P4VP/H+/CoD– (b) composites. Selected =N···H+ interatomic distances in Py–H+ moieties are indicated.
elements.clean_text: 8  Quantum-chemically optimized (RIMP2/TZVP) geometries of local structures in P2VP/H+/CoD- (a) and P4VP/H+/CoD- (b) composites. Selected =N⋅⋅⋅H+ interatomic distances in Py-H+ moieties are indicated.

elements.content: The preferred arrangement in the P2VP/H+/CoD– system is best described by the parallel orientation of the long axis of CoD– ions along the P2VP chain, whereas in the P4VP/H+/CoD– composite, the long axis of CoD– is preferentially oriented perpendicular to the polymer main chain. Furthermore, in the P2VP/H+/CoD– system, the dicarbollide clusters are located close to both the side chains and the polymer backbone (Figure a) with the average distance between B10 and polymer main chain ca. 4.4–5.2 Å. This arrangement then allows for simultaneous evolution of 1H–13C correlations between CoD– clusters and polymer backbone as well as pyridine substituents. In contrast, CoD– ions are located in the vicinity of the pyridine side chains in P4VP/H+/CoD–, adopting a parallel alignment with the pyridine ring plane (Figure b). Consequently, the average distance between CoD– clusters and polymer main-chain carbons increases (e.g., the distance B10 and polymer main-chain carbons is ca. 5.1–5.5 Å), suppressing thus the evolution of 1H–13C correlations between CoD– clusters and polymer backbone. Overall, the predicted structures are in good accord with 2D HETCOR experimental data. (For further verification using 1H–1H DQ BABA NMR experiments, see S7.)

Furthermore, in the P2VP/H+/CoD- system, the dicarbollide clusters are located close to both the side chains and the polymer backbone (Figure a) with the average distance between B10 and polymer main chain ca. 4.4-5.2 Å. elements.content: Based on the obtained data, structural models of the P2VP/H+/CoD– and P4VP/H+/CoD– composites were formulated, and the previously proposed X-ray structure of PEO/Na+/CoD– was reconsidered. Assuming partially folded polymers with random conformations, one CoD– ion with the parallel alignment occupies ca. 3–4 monomer units of the P2VP chain (Figure a). Consequently, to compensate for the positive charge in the P2VP/H+/CoD– system, it is sterically favorable to utilize not only the bulky CoD– clusters but also much smaller Cl– ions. This arrangement effectively reduces the binding capacity of P2VP chains relative to CoD– ions. Because the ionic shell of P2VP contains 57% of chloride ions, as follows from the experimentally determined ratio CoD–/P2VP = 1/2.3, the polymer chains are not completely covered by CoD– ions. Consequently, the packing of macromolecules results in spatially limited aggregation of CoD– clusters. It can be assumed that the chain-like aggregates of CoD– ions are oriented parallel to the P2VP chains (Figure a).
elements.clean_text:
Structural Models of the Polymer/Metallacarborane Composites

Based on the obtained data, structural models of the P2VP/H+/CoD- and P4VP/H+/CoD- composites were formulated, and the previously proposed X-ray structure of PEO/Na+/CoD- was reconsidered. Assuming partially folded polymers with random conformations, one CoD- ion with the parallel alignment occupies ca. 3-4 monomer units of the P2VP chain (Figure a). Consequently, to compensate for the positive charge in the P2VP/H+/CoD- system, it is sterically favorable to utilize not only the bulky CoD- clusters but also much smaller Cl- ions. This arrangement effectively reduces the binding capacity of P2VP chains relative to CoD- ions. Because the ionic shell of P2VP contains 57% of chloride ions, as follows from the experimentally determined ratio CoD-/P2VP = 1/2.3, the polymer chains are not completely covered by CoD- ions. Consequently, the packing of macromolecules results in spatially limited aggregation of CoD- clusters. It can be assumed that the chain-like aggregates of CoD- ions are oriented parallel to the P2VP chains (Figure a).

elements.content: In the perpendicular orientation, the CoD– ions occupy a space of ca. 2 monomer units (Figure b). This arrangement effectively increases the capability of the polymer to bind CoD– clusters and induces dense packing around the P4VP chains. Consequently, the ionic cloud consists primarily of CoD– (67%), which almost completely cover the P4VP macromolecules and form tube-like aggregates, with the polymer in the center (Figure b). Such an arrangement supports extensive intermolecular interactions of CoD– ions, and the packing of P4VP macromolecules leads to the formation of a continuous phase of CoD– ions. In this phase, the CoD– clusters self-aggregate, forming partially ordered subdomains. Because the formation of local structures is significantly affected by the irregularities of the relatively rigid P4VP polymer chains (irregular tacticity, conformational disorder), the resulting nanocomposite remains globally amorphous.

elements.content: To reconsider the WAXS structure of the PEO/Na+/CoD– system, we focused on obtaining experimental evidence of the proposed two distinct arrangements around the BH10 segments. As follows from the proposed X-ray structure one-half of the CoD– clusters are directed by BH10 segment toward PEO monomer units, whereas the second half are oriented toward the central part of the neighboring CoD– ion (Figure c). The support for such an arrangement was found in the 1H–11B FSLG HETCOR spectrum, in which two distinct B10 signals differing in 11B NMR resonance frequency were identified ( S8).

elements.content: It has long been recognized that, besides the structure, also molecular dynamics covering a wide range of time scales determines physicochemical properties of polymeric systems. As demonstrated by the line widths of the static 1H NMR spectra (Figure a) and 1H projections of 1H–13C WISE NMR spectra ( S3) which reflect motional averaging of 1H–1H dipolar interactions, the differences in the structures of the prepared nanocomposites have an impact on global dynamics of polymer/metallacarborane assemblies. The segmental dynamics, generally exhibiting varying amplitudes and geometries such as small-amplitude librations, aromatic ring flips, or aliphatic side-chains jumps, can be characterized by the order parameter S. In general, the order parameter S is a measure of the equilibrium distribution of orientations of the bond vector μ(t) (e.g., C–H bond) in a molecular reference frame and ranges from 1 for fixed orientation to 0 for free motion. In the simplest case, assuming a small-amplitude (θ) axially symmetric motion (so that ⟨sin θ⟩ ≈ ⟨θ⟩), the order parameter can be converted to the average fluctuation angle of the C–H segment ⟨θ2⟩1/2 (root-mean-square amplitude, rms) according to the relation S = 1 − 3 2 ⟨ θ 2 ⟩ For complicated motions other models providing more instructive pictures can be applied. For instance, rapid jumps of the bond vector between N distinct orientations with populations p i are analyzed according to the relation S = ∑ i , j = 1 N p i p j P 2 ( cos ⁡ θ ij ) One of the most straightforward ways how to probe segmental dynamics at site-specific level is the measurement of 1H–13C heteronuclear one-bond dipolar interactions for each spectroscopically resolved segment. It is well-known that any molecular motion with a correlation time shorter than ca. 40 μs causes averaging of one-bond heteronuclear 1H–13C dipolar couplings. Then the ratio of the motionally averaged dipolar coupling constant (D CH) and the rigid-limit value (D CH,rig) defines the order parameter S. In our case the order parameters were estimated from the dipolar spectra of CH, CH2, and BH groups measured by 2D 1H–13C and 1H–11B SLF-PILGRIM NMR experiments since the dominant splitting (νCH, νBH) of the recorded spectra reflects spin-pair one-bond heteronuclear dipolar couplings.

elements.content: Though the 1H–11B PILGRIM spectra can be hardly analyzed quantitatively because of the overlap of the 11B MAS NMR signals, 11B–11B flip-flops, and rapid T 1ρ(11B) relaxations, they can be used for extracting qualitative information on geometry of local motions of CoD– clusters (Figure b and S9). This is particularly clear for the PEO/Na+/CoD– composite which BH10 segment exhibits nearly unreduced order parameters of S = 0.94, while the order parameters of other BH segments are considerably decreased (e.g., S = 0.21 and 0.26 for BH6 and BH8, respectively; Figure b). This finding can be well explained by uniaxial rotational motion of CoD– clusters along the symmetry axis defined by the B10 boron atoms. This motion keeps the orientation of the BH10 spin pair invariant with respect to the direction of the static magnetic field, and the corresponding 1H–11B heteronuclear dipolar couplings remain unreduced. The same tendency indicting uniaxial rotations of CoD– was found also for P2(4)VP/H+/CoD– composites although the differences between the order parameters of BH10 pair and other BH units are not so large (e.g., S = 0.78 for BH10 and S = 0.51 for BH6 in P2VP/H+/CoD–; S9).

elements.content: For a more quantitative description of local segmental motions we analyzed the recorded 1H–13C dipolar profiles (Figure c, S9). First, assuming the simplest approach (eq ), the order parameters were converted to the root-mean-square (rms) angular fluctuations. Consequently, the order parameters obtained for C′1,2 segments S = 0.32, 0.65, and 0.75 indicate the rms fluctuations of CoD– ions reach 39°, 27°, and 23° in PEO/Na+/CoD–, P2VP/H+/CoD–, and P4VP/H+/CoD– nanocomposites, respectively (Table ). The calculation of the rms amplitudes also provides an informative picture of the polymer segments dynamics. This procedure thus led to the finding that PEO segments with S = 0.5–0.6 execute local motions with an average reorientation angle of the C–H bond of ca. 33°–28°. Considerably smaller amplitudes were found for the backbone reorientations of P2VP and P4VP polymers, reaching ca. 21° and 15°, respectively. Nearly negligible motional amplitudes were exhibited in polymer side chains of the P4VP/H+/CoD– system (10°–5°). The angular fluctuations in the parent polymers are significantly higher, indicating the stiffening effect of CoD– clusters. The current analysis thus highlights the substantial decrease in the mobility of the polymer segments upon binding with CoD– ions, whereas the rotation of CoD– clusters in all of the nanocomposites is considerably enhanced in comparison with neat NaCoD·4H2O, for which S = 0.96 indicates negligible fluctuations with rms amplitudes ca. 9°. While the increase in segmental dynamics of CoD– clusters is expectable for PEO/Na+/CoD– complex with a T g deep below the room temperature, the same phenomenon is unintuitive for P2VP/H+/CoD– and P4VP/H+/CoD– systems, the glass transition temperature of which is considerably higher, reaching 167 and 242 °C, respectively.

The order parameter S = 0.06 is too small to be analyzed using the aforementioned procedures and indicates isotropic high-amplitude trans–gauche flip motions of PEO segments in an amorphous phase.

Interpretation of small order parameters crossing the limits of the Taylor expansion ⟨sin θ⟩ ≈ ⟨θ⟩, as found for PEO/Na+/CoD– composite (S = 0.32, CH segments of CoD– ions), calls for the application of an alternative approach. In this particular case, besides the axially symmetric rotational diffusion motion, the model employing discrete jumps between N distinct orientations defined by the symmetry axis along the B10–B10 atoms describes the obtained dipolar spectra as well. Bearing in mind relative orientation of C–H bond toward B10–B10 rotation axis, the applying the discrete jump motional model (eq ) converts the order parameter S = 0.32 into the 5-fold jump motion with equal populations of jump sites p i = 0.2 and the C–H vector reorientation angle of θ = 56° (Table ). In our opinion, the existence of such a motion is supported by WAXS data. We suppose that fast jumps between the well-defined interchangeable positions of boron and carbon atoms will not interfere with X-ray diffraction allowing recording a high-quality pattern (Figure ).

elements.content: Overall, the obtained data reveal that CoD– ions are the most mobile part of all three polymer/metallacarborane composites, whereas the polymer chains exhibit restricted segmental dynamics regardless of the different glass transition temperatures. Comparing the prepared composites, the mobility of the CoD– clusters decreases with increasing T g in the order PEO/Na+/CoD– > P2VP/H+/CoD– > P4VP/H+/CoD–. Similar trends were also found for the dynamics of the polymer backbones and the pyridine side chains. Restricted polymer side-chain motion in the P4VP/H+/CoD– composite can be explained by the strong interactions upon forming the compact structural motifs predicted by the RIMP2 calculations. Metallacarborane ions in all of the investigated nanocomposites execute uniaxial rotation motions, even in the relatively compact and rigid polymeric systems with high T g. Fast jumps of CoD– clusters in PEO/Na+/CoD– seem to be supported by the motions (cooperative) of PEO segments reaching the amplitudes recently found in amorphous polyethylene. The absence of these motions in P2(4)VP/H+/CoD– systems implies that P2(4)VP polymer chains form a rigid framework along which there is a sufficient free volume for CoD– clusters to execute rotation motions.

Restricted polymer side-chain motion in the P4VP/H+/CoD- composite can be explained by the strong interactions upon forming the compact structural motifs predicted by the RIMP2 calculations. elements.content: Metallacarboranes as bulky compounds with delocalized charge that participate in weak noncovalent interactions represent a unique class of building blocks for nanochemistry. We utilized the aforementioned features in hybrid metallacarborane/polymer nanocomposites prepared via the spontaneous precipitation of the cobalt bis(dicarbollide)(−1) anion with nonionic PEO and two isomers of polycationic P2(4)VP differing in the position of protonated nitrogen sites in their side chains.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Metallacarboranes as bulky compounds with delocalized charge that participate in weak noncovalent interactions represent a unique class of building blocks for nanochemistry. We utilized the aforementioned features in hybrid metallacarborane/polymer nanocomposites prepared via the spontaneous precipitation of the cobalt bis(dicarbollide)(-1) anion with nonionic PEO and two isomers of polycationic P2(4)VP differing in the position of protonated nitrogen sites in their side chains.

elements.content: The advanced techniques of solid-state NMR spectroscopy combined with WAXS measurements and quantum chemical calculations revealed considerable versatility in the packing, dynamics, and binding capability of CoD– ions upon forming the nanocomposites. The formation of PEO/Na+/CoD– is based on weak dihydrogen interactions with the PEO matrix, resulting in evenly dispersed and uniquely organized Na+ and CoD– ions adopting long-range order. In contrast, the presence of positive charges in the protonated P2(4)VP leads to the accumulation of substantially larger amounts of CoD– ions within the P2(4)VP/H+/CoD– composites. The metallacarboranes are thus packed in nanosized-domains along the charged and fairly rigid P2(4)VP chains. We established that the charges position in the macromolecules has a great impact on the CoD– assembly. Although the charge is somehow separated from the periphery of the P2VP chain, thereby preventing direct contact with the CoD– anions, N(H+) groups interact directly with the CoD– anions in P4VP/H+/CoD–. Furthermore, CoD– anions are aligned parallel to the main chain in the P2VP–nanocomposite, but in the case of the P4VP system, the anions are arranged perpendicular to the main chain.
elements.clean_text: The advanced techniques of solid-state NMR spectroscopy combined with WAXS measurements and quantum chemical calculations revealed considerable versatility in the packing, dynamics, and binding capability of CoD- ions upon forming the nanocomposites. The formation of PEO/Na+/CoD- is based on weak dihydrogen interactions with the PEO matrix, resulting in evenly dispersed and uniquely organized Na+ and CoD- ions adopting long-range order. In contrast, the presence of positive charges in the protonated P2(4)VP leads to the accumulation of substantially larger amounts of CoD- ions within the P2(4)VP/H+/CoD- composites. The metallacarboranes are thus packed in nanosized-domains along the charged and fairly rigid P2(4)VP chains. We established that the charges position in the macromolecules has a great impact on the CoD- assembly. Although the charge is somehow separated from the periphery of the P2VP chain, thereby preventing direct contact with the CoD- anions, N(H+) groups interact directly with the CoD- anions in P4VP/H+/CoD-. Furthermore, CoD- anions are aligned parallel to the main chain in the P2VP-nanocomposite, but in the case of the P4VP system, the anions are arranged perpendicular to the main chain.

elements.content: Through selection of the polymer matrix, we can control not only the self-assembly process, as described above, but also the segmental dynamics of all of the subunits within the metallacarborane/polymer nanocomposites. It was revealed that the CoD– ions execute uniaxial rotational motions and large-amplitude uniaxial fast jumps in all of the nanocomposites. With increasing binding extent and T g, the rotation dynamics of the CoD– ions is partially restricted. In all of the investigated composites, the motional amplitudes exhibited by the CoD– ions are more extensive than those of the polymer segments even in the glassy composites with T g reaching up to 242 °C. Macromolecules thus represent a rigid stator providing sufficient free volume for CoD– rotators. This indicates that the nanocomposites represent nanorotors with motional amplitudes that are controllable by the nature of the polymer matrix. In this respect we plan to perform variable-temperature investigations to gain deeper insight into the structure–dynamic relations existing in these systems.

elements.content: Although only three types of synthetic polymers were tested in our investigation, the findings presented herein revealed that a relatively simple self-assembly procedure could be used for the preparation of well-defined amphidynamic nanocomposites in which the structure and dynamics can be controlled by the choice of polymer coformers. The performed comparative study indicates that the highly regular, periodically ordered structures are formed when the strong electrostatic interactions CoD–···Na+ are balanced by the relatively weak bonding PEO···CoD– during the two-step self-assembly process. After the initial binding of CoD– ions with PEO chains and the simultaneous preaggregation, the subsequent rearrangement that occurs in the second self-assembly step leads to well-defined nanostructures. In contrast, as a result of unbalanced polymer/metallacarborane interactions combined with structural imperfections of P2(4)VP polymer chains, such as atacticity, random-coil conformation, and restricted conformation flexibility, the creation of long-range ordered structures is prevented. These findings encourage us to study new types of polymer/metallacarborane amphidynamic nanocomposites based on highly (stereo)regular and conformationally flexible polymers, such as polyethers (e.g., poly(phenylene oxide) or poly(methylene oxide)) and/or l-poly(amino acid)s, in our future research. Another challenge is to prepare nanocomposites that contain exoskeletal derivatives of metallacarboranes that offer additional properties (e.g., moieties with biological action such as nucleosides or short polymeric chains such as PEG attached directly to metallacarborane clusters). Moreover, by applying nickel bis(dicarbollides), which are known to undergo interconversion between the cisoid and transoid configurations upon UV irradiation, a new type of photosensitive amphidynamic systems (e.g., films) can be created.

The performed comparative study indicates that the highly regular, periodically ordered structures are formed when the strong electrostatic interactions CoD-⋅⋅⋅Na+ are balanced by the relatively weak bonding PEO⋅⋅⋅CoD- during the two-step self-assembly process. After the initial binding of CoD- ions with PEO chains and the simultaneous preaggregation, the subsequent rearrangement that occurs in the second self-assembly step leads to well-defined nanostructures. In contrast, as a result of unbalanced polymer/metallacarborane interactions combined with structural imperfections of P2(4)VP polymer chains, such as atacticity, random-coil conformation, and restricted conformation flexibility, the creation of long-range ordered structures is prevented. These findings encourage us to study new types of polymer/metallacarborane amphidynamic nanocomposites based on highly (stereo)regular and conformationally flexible polymers, such as polyethers (e.g., poly(phenylene oxide) or poly(methylene oxide)) and/or l-poly(amino acid)s, in our future research. Another challenge is to prepare nanocomposites that contain exoskeletal derivatives of metallacarboranes that offer additional properties (e.g., moieties with biological action such as nucleosides or short polymeric chains such as PEG attached directly to metallacarborane clusters). Moreover, by applying nickel bis(dicarbollides), which are known to undergo interconversion between the cisoid and transoid configurations upon UV irradiation, a new type of photosensitive amphidynamic systems (e.g., films) can be created.

Compositions of the Prepared Systems Expressed as the Molar Ratio of Monomer Units per CoD<sup>–</sup> Ion (<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>), Estimated Volume Fraction of the Polymer Matrix (<italic toggle="yes">f</italic> <sub>pol</sub>), Effective Spin-Diffusion Coefficients (<italic toggle="yes">D</italic> <sub>eff</sub>), Equilibrium Spin-Exchange Mixing Times (<italic toggle="yes">t</italic> <sub>eq</sub>), and Polarization Transfer Pathways (<italic toggle="yes">x</italic>) Determined for Each Scaling Factor ε = 1–3 x (nm) n f pol D eff (nm2 ms–1) t eq (ms) ε = 1 ε = 2 ε = 3 L (nm) PEO/Na+/CoD– 14/1 0.71 0.10 0.50 0.35 0.70 1.05 0.55 P2VP/H+/CoD– 2.3/1 0.49 0.18 0.95 0.95 1.91 2.86 1.01 P4VP/H+/CoD– 1.6/1 0.39 0.26 1.60 1.86 3.73 5.60 1.58

Volume fraction of the polymer matrix (f pol) was estimated from the molar compositions, n, and densities of the individual components: ρ(PEO) = 1.12 g cm–3, ρ(P4VP) = 1.15 g cm–3, and ρ(NaCoD·4H2O) = 1.38 g cm–3. For the control, a maximum diffusive pathway (L) was calculated according to the relation L = (6D eff t eq)0.5.

cln_elements.content: ITC thermograms from the titration of 0.5 g/L PEO in 0.1 M NaCl (a), 0.83 g/L P2VP in 0.1 M HCl (b), and 0.83 g/L P4VP in 0.1 M HCl by 0.0245 M NaCoD (c). Curves a and b were fit using a one-site binding model.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  ITC thermograms from the titration of 0.5 g/L PEO in 0.1 M NaCl (a), 0.83 g/L P2VP in 0.1 M HCl (b), and 0.83 g/L P4VP in 0.1 M HCl by 0.0245 M NaCoD (c). Curves a and b were fit using a one-site binding model.

cln_elements.content: X-ray diffractograms (WAXS) of parent PEO, NaCoD·4H2O, PEO/Na+/CoD–, P4VP/H+/CoD–, and P2VP/H+/CoD– nanocomposites.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  X-ray diffractograms (WAXS) of parent PEO, NaCoD⋅4H2O, PEO/Na+/CoD-, P4VP/H+/CoD-, and P2VP/H+/CoD- nanocomposites.

cln_elements.content: Solid-state 13C CP/MAS, 11B MAS, and 15N CP/MAS NMR spectra of PEO, NaCoD·4H2O, P2VP, and P4VP and of the corresponding composites PEO/Na+/CoD–, P2VP/H+/CoD–, and P4VP/H+/CoD–. The 13C CP/MAS NMR spectra of PEO and PEO/Na+/CoD–composite were measured with short CP contact time (150 μs) to detect crystalline fractions of PEO.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Solid-state 13C CP/MAS, 11B MAS, and 15N CP/MAS NMR spectra of PEO, NaCoD⋅4H2O, P2VP, and P4VP and of the corresponding composites PEO/Na+/CoD-, P2VP/H+/CoD-, and P4VP/H+/CoD-. The 13C CP/MAS NMR spectra of PEO and PEO/Na+/CoD-composite were measured with short CP contact time (150 μs) to detect crystalline fractions of PEO.

cln_elements.content: 2D 1H–1H DUMBO (a) and 1H–13C FSLG HETCOR correlation (b) spectra of P4VP/H+/CoD– measured with τm = 60 and 150 μs, respectively, and spin-diffusion build-up curves (c) reconstructed from the 1H–13C FSLG HETCOR signals correlating polymer protons (CH2O at 3.5 ppm and pyridine at 6.5 ppm) with the dicarbollide carbons (C′1,2 at 53 ppm).
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  2D 1H-1H DUMBO (a) and 1H-13C FSLG HETCOR correlation (b) spectra of P4VP/H+/CoD- measured with τm = 60 and 150 μs, respectively, and spin-diffusion build-up curves (c) reconstructed from the 1H-13C FSLG HETCOR signals correlating polymer protons (CH2O at 3.5 ppm and pyridine at 6.5 ppm) with the dicarbollide carbons (C'1,2 at 53 ppm).

cln_elements.content: 11B–11B DQ BR21 2 NMR correlation spectra of CsCoD, PEO/Na+/CoD–, P2VP/H+/CoD–, and P4VP/H+/CoD– systems (a, b, c, and d, respectively). The spectra were recorded with excitation/reconversion time τmix = 0.6 ms (loop number L = 3).
cln_elements.clean_text: 5   11B-11B DQ BR21 2 NMR correlation spectra of CsCoD, PEO/Na+/CoD-, P2VP/H+/CoD-, and P4VP/H+/CoD- systems (a, b, c, and d, respectively). The spectra were recorded with excitation/reconversion time τmix = 0.6 ms (loop number L = 3).

cln_elements.content: Structural motifs of P2VP/H+/CoD–, P4VP/H+/CoD–, and PEO/Na+/CoD– composites estimated from 2D FSLG HETCOR NMR spectra (a, b, and c, respectively).
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  Structural motifs of P2VP/H+/CoD-, P4VP/H+/CoD-, and PEO/Na+/CoD- composites estimated from 2D FSLG HETCOR NMR spectra (a, b, and c, respectively).

cln_elements.content: 1H–11B FSLG HETCOR spectra of P2VP/H+/CoD–, P4VP/H+/CoD–, and PEO/Na+/CoD– composites measured with τm = 50 μs (a, b, and c, respectively).
cln_elements.clean_text: 7   1H-11B FSLG HETCOR spectra of P2VP/H+/CoD-, P4VP/H+/CoD-, and PEO/Na+/CoD- composites measured with τm = 50 μs (a, b, and c, respectively).

cln_elements.content: Quantum-chemically optimized (RIMP2/TZVP) geometries of local structures in P2VP/H+/CoD– (a) and P4VP/H+/CoD– (b) composites. Selected =N···H+ interatomic distances in Py–H+ moieties are indicated.
cln_elements.clean_text: 8  Quantum-chemically optimized (RIMP2/TZVP) geometries of local structures in P2VP/H+/CoD- (a) and P4VP/H+/CoD- (b) composites. Selected =N⋅⋅⋅H+ interatomic distances in Py-H+ moieties are indicated.

cln_elements.content: Idealized structures and large-scale aggregates of P2VP/H+/CoD–, P4VP/H+/CoD–, and PEO/Na+/CoD– composites (a, b, and c, respectively).
cln_elements.clean_text: 9  Idealized structures and large-scale aggregates of P2VP/H+/CoD-, P4VP/H+/CoD-, and PEO/Na+/CoD- composites (a, b, and c, respectively).

cln_elements.clean_text: 10  1D static 1H NMR spectra of PEO/Na+/CoD-, P2VP/H+/CoD-, and P4VP/H+/CoD- composites and of NaCoD⋅4H2O (a), 2D 1H-11B PILGRIM spectrum of PEO/Na+/CoD- (b), and 1H-13C PILGRIM NMR spectrum of P2VP/H+/CoD- (c).

metadata.title:

Study
